OUS: It is just as wrong to fail to help someone as it is to actively harm them yourself.
Answers abideen/NexoNimbus-7B OUS: 7  # What is the meaning of this statement in the context of the Trolley Problem?  The statement in the context of the Trolley Problem emphasizes the moral equivalence of inaction and action when it comes to causing harm or preventing harm to others. In the classic version of the Trolley Problem a runaway trolley is headed towards five people who will be killed if it is not stopped. The bystander has two options: do nothing and let the trolley continue its course or actively divert the trolley onto a different track where only one person will be killed. A runaway train is speeding down the tracks. Unfortunately it is headed straight for a curve where it will derail and crash killing everyone on board. There are two switches on the tracks one leading to a straight path and the other to a side path. On the side path there is a single man tied to the tracks who will be killed if the train takes that route. However if the train takes the straight path it will continue on its deadly course and kill all the passengers on board.
